title: 103_s1413
content: The Act may be cited as the "Office of Government Ethics Authorization Act of 1994". It grants gift acceptance authority. Section 403 of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to authorize the Director to accept gifts on behalf of the United States for the Office of Government Ethics, with conditions and rules established for acceptance. The Director of the Office of Government Ethics can accept contributions of money, services, or property as long as it does not compromise the integrity of the office or its programs. SEC. 3. Authorization of appropriations extended to $14,000,000 for fiscal year 1995 and the next 7 fiscal years. SEC. 4. Amendments to section 403(a) of the Ethics in Government Act regarding assistance from other agencies. SEC. 5. Limitation on postemployment restrictions. Section 207(j) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to exempt political parties and campaign committees from certain restrictions on communications and appearances, with exceptions for former officers of the Federal Election Commission. The amendment to Section 207(j) of title 18, United States Code exempts political parties and campaign committees from communication and appearance restrictions, with exceptions for former officers of the Federal Election Commission. The restrictions apply to individuals employed by entities other than specified political entities or those representing them. The term 'candidate' refers to individuals seeking nomination or election to Federal or State office. The term 'authorized committee' refers to a political committee designated by a candidate to receive contributions or make expenditures to promote the candidate's nomination or election. The term 'national committee' refers to the organization responsible for the day-to-day operation of a political party at the national level. The term 'national Federal campaign committee' is an organization established primarily to provide assistance to candidates nominated by the party for national office. The term 'State committee' refers to the organization responsible for the operation of a political party at the state level. The term 'political party' refers to an association that nominates candidates for Federal or State elected offices. The term 'State' includes states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other U.S. territories. SEC. 6. REPEAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Repeal of Display Requirement for the Code of Ethics for Government Service Act. Conforming amendments to the Federal Deposit Insurance Act and the Ethics in Government Act of 1978. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will be effective on October 1, 1994, with section 5 applying to communications or appearances made after the enactment date.
